title: Susan B. Anthony Papers: Daybook and Diaries, 1856-1906; Diaries; 1900

entries.fullText:
There will be three Eclipses this year, two of the Sun and
one of the Moon, as follows:

I. A Total Eclipse of the Sun, May 28, visible as a partial
eclipse throughout most of the U.S. The line of totality
extends from Norfolk, VA., to Mobile and New Orleans.

Boston.
Begins 8.9 A.M.
Middle 9.29 A.M.
Ends 10.50 A.M.

New York.
Begins 7.49 A.M.
Middle 9.10 A.M.
Ends 10.31 A.M.

Washington.
Begins 7.40 A.M.
Middle 8.55 A.M.
Ends 10.11 A.M.

II. A Partial Eclipse of the Moon, June 13. This is so
small as to scarcely amount to more than a contact, and de-
tails are therefore omitted.

III. An Annual Eclipse of the Sun, Nov. 22, invisible in
America.
entries.summaryText: There will be three Eclipses this year, two of the Sun and one of the Moon, as follows.

Poisons
and Antidotes.

FIRST.--Send for a physician.
SECOND.--INDUCE VOMITING, by tickling throat with
feather or finger. Drink hot water or strong mustard and
water. Swallow sweet oil or whites of eggs.
Acids are antidotes for alkalies, and vice versa.

ACIDS, MINERAL.--Chalk, magnesia (plaster off wall in
emergency), solution carbonate of soda, emollient drinks,
fixed oils.
ACID, CARBOLIC.--Any soluble sulphate, such as mag-
esia.
ACID, HYDROCYANIC.--Fresh air and artificial respira-
tion, with cold effusion. Ammonia by inhalation and in-
travenously in vein of leg.
ACONITE.--Emetics, stimulants, external and internal ;
keep up external heat, keep flat on back.
ANTIMONY TART.--Vegetable acids, such as tannic acid,
catechu. *
ARSENIC.--Freshly precipitated hydrated sesquioxide of
iron made by adding magnesia to any iron solution.
ATROPIA.--Same as Belladonna.
BELLADONNA.--Emetics--mustard flour in water ; give
physostigma or pilocarpine ; cold to head.
CANTHARIDES.--Emetics, emollient drinks, opiates by
mouth and rectum, large draughts of water to flush kidneys.
CHLORINE WATER.--Albumen, white of egg, milk,
flour.
CHLOROFORM.--Fresh air, artifical respiration (inclin-
ing head down, pull tongue forward), brandy and ammonia
intravenously in leg, the HYPODERMIC injection of 15 m.
tincture of digitalis and I-60 of a grain of atropine.
COLCHICUM.--Emetics, followed by demulcent drinks.
If coma be present brandy, ammonia, coffee. Opium in
large dose. Keep up external heat.
CONIUM.--Emetics, followed by stimulants external and
internal.
CORROSIVE SUBLIMATE.--Albumen, white of egg (4 gr.
sublimate require white of one egg), flour, milk, Equal
parts of lime water and milk. Emetics, or evacuate stomach
by pump.
entries.summaryText: A list of poisons and their antidotes, along with instructions on how to induce vomiting and other emergency procedures.

entries.fullText:
Strange to leave of 18, begin
with 1900 - Mrs Harper here -
writing syndicate for McClure - on
the Queen - & compiling leaflet
with extracts from all the favorable
reports ever made in the two
houses of Congress -- Miss
Hanley at work helping us - Little
Anna E Dann - still doing the
house work - though going to
School of Stenography 5 half days
of each week - Sister Mary
watching everything & everybody to
see that all goes to order -
Mrs Sarah Calman Blackall called
- said it was 11 years today that they
were married - Gertud[g?]e, Robert,
Minnie & Florence - all [?] nice
[?] their children - we ate her
plum pudding [?] -
very cold -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about various people who visited her, including Mrs Harper, Miss Hanley, Anna E Dann, Sister Mary, Mrs Sarah Calman Blackall, Gertrude, Robert, Minnie, and Florence. She also mentions compiling a leaflet and eating plum pudding.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Harper and self
worked all day on
the Congressional action
material for leaflet --
The snow falling & wind
blowing furiously all day -
- It is now nearly a
month - since I have
taken a real out of door
turn - as has always
been my practice - nothing but
sheer dread of [Nix?] cold
& willingness to keep [?]
The interview of Mrs Harpers
for McClure's Syndicate
is very nice.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Mrs. Harper worked on the Congressional action material for a leaflet. Susan has not been outside for almost a month due to the cold. Mrs. Harper's interview for McClure's Syndicate is nice.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Harper took 6.44 A.M.
train - Northern Central for Washington
D.C. -due in at 7.15 -
We were all up and at table at 5.30
- the wind gone - but the cold
hangs on - snow flurrying -
1st School-board meeting
at 4. this P.M., Mrs Helen
Barett Montgomery, - with four
men - Townson, Forbes and Dr. Carroll,
Chamberlain - conplete it - had
written & telephoned Mrs [Oban], [Easterman], Garnett - asking them
to present
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper left for Washington D.C. Susan B. Anthony attended a School-board meeting with Mrs Helen Barett Montgomery, Townson, Forbes, Dr. Carroll, and Chamberlain. Mrs. Montgomery had written and telephoned Mrs [Oban], [Easterman], Garnett to ask them to present.

entries.fullText: At home working all forenoon to get off letters - second ones to delinquent State Presidents - to copy again & return to me petitions to Congress on 16th amt [and?] "Made" in the Island [?]. Have received & sent on from 22 States - the other 25 - Presidents have to be pelted again. At 3 P.M. attended Local Council - it decided to take raising Co. Ed. Fund for Rochester meeting as its next work - having [?] its first job - that of getting a woman Mrs Montgomery elected to the School Board
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony worked from home sending letters and petitions to Congress. She attended a Local Council meeting and discussed raising funds for a Rochester meeting and getting Mrs. Montgomery elected to the School Board.

entries.fullText: At home Speak at 2 P.M. before the Brick Layers & Stone Masons International Council at Odd Fellows Hall -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at the Brick Layers & Stone Masons International Council at Odd Fellows Hall.

Wea. SAT. JAN, 27, 2900 Ther.
Wea. SUN. JAN. 28, 1900 Ther.
Wea. MON. JAN. 29, 1900 Ther.

Mrs. C.B. Colby - 2420 - 14th st - 8. P.M.
The Law School [hangout?] - 10 - P.M,
entries.summaryText: Mrs. C.B. Colby visited at 2420 - 14th st at 8 P.M. and later went to The Law School at 10 P.M.

entries.fullText: Wea. MON., FEB. 5, 1900 Ther.

The Washington Club - at
11.30 - Mrs. Susan Mills - Mrs. M. Neil,
Miss Jarvis -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with Mrs. Susan Mills, Mrs. M. Neil, and Miss Jarvis at The Washington Club.

Wea. THURS. FEB. 8, 1900 Ther.

At the Riggs
80th Birthday at Lafayette
Opera House 3 P.M. -

entries.fullText:
Ex.Com. Meeting National Council
Riggs House - 10.30 oclock A.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended an Executive Committee meeting for the National Council at Riggs House.

at the Riggs

At The Riggs
In B. C. meetings

P. M. & evening.

entries.fullText:
At the Riggs
The Business Com
meetings all day long
Mrs. McCullough
and baby boy left on the
6 P.M. train for
Chicago--
entries.summaryText: Attended Business Committee meetings at The Riggs all day. Mrs. McCullough and her baby boy left for Chicago on the 6 P.M. train.

entries.fullText:
At the Riggs
Rev Anna Shaw & [?]
Irving E. left for Phila
at 12.05. and
Alice Stone Blackwell
at 3 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Rev Anna Shaw, Irving E., Alice Stone Blackwell left for Phila from Riggs.

entries.fullText:
At the Riggs
Mrs. Foster Avery & Nicolas
took the 12.05 train for
Phila. Wrote 8 letters
to U.S. Senators enclosing
Petition for Hawaiian
women. Had
callers & forgot to take
lunch. So ate early dinner.
& when the Ten times
Ten club banquet came
I had no eating capacity--
It was a most inferior
display of womans' talent
Sarah Spencer the Pres.
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Foster Avery and Nicolas left for Phila from Riggs. Susan B. Anthony wrote 8 letters to U.S. Senators enclosing Petition for Hawaiian women. Had callers and forgot to take lunch. Ate early dinner and had no eating capacity for the Ten times Ten club banquet. Sarah Spencer was the President.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Upton left at 10. A.M.
for New York -
at 10:30 - Mrs. Catt
accompanied me to the
Grand (Albaugh's) Opera
House - & President
General presented
me to the Daughters
of the American Revolution -
& afterward Mrs. Catt -
quite a recognition -
This is the 3rd year in
succession that I have
been presented first by Mrs.
Adele Stevenson, &
2nd & 3rd by Mrs. Manning.
After this Mrs. C.,Miss Hay
& self went to the Capital. I talked &
lunched with Senator Warren
of Wyoming, dined with Dr. &
Mrs. [Lindell?] & spent evening with
Mrs [Hemstreet?]
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Upton left for New York, Mrs. Catt presented me to the Daughters of the American Revolution, and I spent time with various people.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Catt and Miss Hay left
at 12:05 train.
Dr. James Dickinson
& self walked out - & I
got my little clock that
Mrs. [Purie?] of Indianapolis
gave me on Birthday --
Joseph H. Douglass
son of Charles Douglass, the
youngest son of Frederick
Douglass, - Joseph's mother
was Elizabeth Murphy -
called - so all my B.G left
me - Mrs. [Mench?] of New
Orleans - & Mrs. [Southwater?]
of Ohio still at hotel.
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Catt and Miss Hay left, I received a clock as a gift, and Joseph H. Douglass visited me.

entries.fullText:
Arrived at 2pm at
Mrs. Mary Foote Henderson
Mrs. J.B. 16th st &
Mrs. Swift of Cal. Mrs. Harper
Mrs. Walworth. & Mr & Mrs
Edson. Nephew of dear
Dr. Wasdon Edson. then
also Dr. Dan Snyder of
St Louis there.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Washington and met with several people including Mrs. Mary Foote Henderson, Mrs. J.B., Mrs. Swift, Mrs. Harper, Mrs. Walworth, Mr & Mrs Edson, Dr. Wasdon Edson, and Dr. Dan Snyder.

entries.fullText:
Went to Luncheon at
Mrs. Julia L. Langdon Barbers--
who with Mrs. Henderson
join with me in taking
out incorporation papers
for Anthony Standing Fund
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to a luncheon at Mrs. Julia L. Langdon Barbers' house and discussed taking out incorporation papers for Anthony Standing Fund with Mrs. Henderson.

entries.fullText:
Brother J. Merritt is 66
years old to day - he must get
my letter & $25 check by this time
His letter two days after this date
said he felt unworthy of such
kindness from brother D.R. & me--
entries.summaryText: Journal entry on April 19, 1900 about Brother J. Merritt's birthday and a letter sent to him.

entries.fullText:
At home.
Pushing away on letters
& [?] on house
cleaning.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home, working on letters and house cleaning.

entries.fullText:
At home.
Trying to get along
with answering birth
day letters but house
cleaning with Anna D,
& working half time with
Miss Hawley makes very
slow work.
At 9.20 evening. Mrs.
Harper arrived. to
begin work on History of
W.S.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home, struggling to balance answering birthday letters, house cleaning with Anna D, and working half time with Miss Hawley. Mrs. Harper arrives in the evening to begin work on the History of W.S.

entries.fullText:
At home.
Mrs. Harper & self talked
over the ground--ready
to begin work tomorrow.
Nephew D.R.A. Jr. arrived
at 2.30 p.m. and
spent night-- & left after
breakfast Monday A.M.
He is a fine appearing
young man-- The front
rooms up & down stairs
are cleaner--Carpets
down & in order. The
new parlor rugs are
admired very much.
This is little Eliza
T's birthday. She would
have been? She is? 68
years old today!! She was
2 years & 3 days old when brother
Merritt was born-- April 19, 1834.
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper & self talked over the ground--ready to begin work tomorrow. Nephew D.R.A. Jr. arrived and spent the night. Eliza T's birthday. Rooms are cleaner and new parlor rugs are admired.

entries.fullText:
At Home
Mrs. Harper & self worked on
the four forms of letters to delegates
to the 4 National Cons. Prohib,
Pop. Dem. Repub-- & sent
copies to New President-- Mrs.
Catt of Little Rock, Ark &
Clarksdale Miss.--her for approval--
House cleaning of kitchen
washing &c going on--
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper & self worked on the four forms of letters to delegates. House cleaning of kitchen washing &c going on.

entries.fullText:
At Home.
Judge Wm Stuart
buried at 2.30 this P.M.
Sister Mary & self went
to house. Dr. Riggs of St. Peters
Church officiated. Reading Paul's
imagination of death &
the hereafter-- much to
believers in special inspiration of
every word in the Bible-- but
to us no more than any
man's ideas regarding future.
Called on Sam'l Wylder
at his home East
Avenue-- he has been ill & a
shut-in all Winter--but
now hope to get out to drive
--after, this called on Mrs. Prof
Latimore--then on Mrs. Black
all--Mrs B. Sitting on front porch
--then stopped of engaged paper &
hanger for Thursday.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending Judge Wm Stuart's funeral, visiting sick friends, and running errands.

entries.fullText: At Home.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes that she is at home.

entries.fullText:
My friend, May Wright Sewall
arrived at 9 A.M. from Indianapolis.
Gave her my west end bedroom
She sat down in front chamber
with Mrs. Harper and self-- & gave us
the history of her commission from
Pres. McKinley which proves to be a
beautiful letter of introduction
to the French Powers that he
over the Paris Exposition.
entries.summaryText: May Wright Sewall arrived from Indianapolis and gave a history of her commission from Pres. McKinley regarding the Paris Exposition.

entries.fullText:
Went Lehigh Valley station
with M. W. Sewell 9.20. & then
to Junction-- Had nice talk-- Then
back to church-- & heard Mr.
Gannett on material reasons for
rejoicing in being Unitarian. Said
he was thankful for being born
a Unitarian & so am I thankful
for having been born a Friend
--a Quaker--to be born
into a free religious world is a
great blessing indeed--
entries.summaryText: Accompanied M. W. Sewell to Lehigh Valley station and Junction, then attended church and heard Mr. Gannett speak on material reasons for rejoicing in being Unitarian.

geographicalLocations: Irondequoit D. A. R. Chapter - Reynolds LibraryHall
entries.fullText:
At home.
Went to Dentist Josephine
Requa - had a left eye tooth
fitted - & am to go again Wednesday -
In P. M. Mrs Harper
& self went to Irondequoit
D. A. R. Chapter - Reynolds
LibraryHall -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to the dentist and then attended a D.A.R. Chapter meeting in Irondequoit.

entries.fullText:
At Home -
To speak for Jewish
Club - Jony Boy's Home - [near?]
in Free Academy - to come for me:
Had a good time - many
questions asked.

also, at exhibition of
the Cooking - Public school
children - at Fitzhughs Hall
4:30 - Prof Henry Lodish
invited me - he pays
for free lessons in the
Public & Parochial Schools
Mrs Sarah Dix
mother of Ella, Florence & James
Dix - there to see the work
of her grand-daughters Florence
& Marion Dix Mosher -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at the Jewish Club and attended a cooking exhibition at Fitzhughs Hall where she was invited by Prof Henry Lodish. She also met Mrs Sarah Dix and saw the work of her grand-daughters Florence and Marion Dix Mosher.

entries.fullText: Wea. FRI. MAY 4, 1900 Ther.

At home
A little after 9 A.M.
little Merritt Dix Mosher
bro't a note from his mother
Ella Dix Mosher - Saying
" Our dear Mother passed away
suddenly this morning at 6.30 oclock
I went back with the boy -
& there in her bed - lay the lifeless
body of Mrs Sarah
Dix - wife of Samuel Dix who
passed years ago - Mrs Dix
was at her Science Meeting
Wednesday evening - after getting home
both she & her daughter Ella
ate a doughnut - at once Mrs
D. remarked that she feared
she ought not to have eaten it -
- Was restless that night - &
had been as she called it -
suffering from indigestion since -
- not sleeping much if any - &
Ella had lain on Sofa in
her mothers room - at 4 this A. M.
she said she felt cold - Ella sent
girl Ada for Miss Wooden & Dr Smith
but at 6.30 - she stopped breathing!! —
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Sarah Dix, wife of Samuel Dix, passed away suddenly at 6:30 AM. She had been suffering from indigestion since eating a doughnut on Wednesday evening and had not been sleeping well. Her daughter, Ella, was with her when she passed away.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote that she was at home on May 6, 1900.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote that she was at home on May 7, 1900.

entries.fullText:
Niece H. Louise Mosher, James
came from Phila. in time for
7 o'clock breakfast. I
went to Mrs. Dix's with her -
she & her brother Frank came
to dinner - & she & I both
took a napp - - Mr. Charles
Proctor came + told us the
Health Officer - Dr. Zola
would not give a burial
permit for Mrs. Dix - in the
Christian Science Dr. Smith's
certificate of death from
"heart-failure" & a second
one that added profuse [?]
bleeding.
entries.summaryText: Niece H. Louise Mosher and James visit. Mrs. Dix's burial permit is denied due to a certificate of death from Dr. Smith.

entries.fullText:
Funeral of Mrs. Sarah
Dix - wife of Samuel Dix
& mother of nephew
Frank Mosher's wife
Ella Dix - at 2.30, this P.M.
Rev. Stebbins of Central
Presbyterian Church
officiated - Mr. & Mrs. Dix,
Members of that church all their
lives here - until a year ago Mrs.
D. took her letter - and has
gone with her daughter
Ella to Christian Science
meetings in Cox Building
Mrs. Pine - read Bible & Mrs.
Eddy's book & talked --
entries.summaryText: Funeral of Mrs. Sarah Dix, who had recently joined Christian Science meetings in Cox Building.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: At home

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: At home

entries.fullText: At home.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote that she was at home.

entries.fullText: At home. Niece Louise went to Church with us - much to Frank & Ella's sorrow. She dined at the Dix & all went out to Mt Hope
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote that her niece Louise went to church with them and dined at the Dix, and they all went out to Mt Hope.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote that she was at home.

entries.fullText: At Home. went to Dr Regna's this A.M. Niece Louise Mosher James left on 12.35 Black Diamond for home. was here just a week - Sister May & nephew Frank up. Lydia really taken with him In P.M. telegram from Harriet May Mills says "father died today" - funeral at 4.30 tomorrow - so I must go -- Later came a second telegram begging me to be with them & I had before written them I would go --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about her daily activities, visitors, and receiving a telegram about a death in the family. She decided to attend the funeral after receiving a second telegram.

entries.fullText:
Took the 9.05 train -
arrived Syracuse after or just
before 11 - went direct to
926 West Genesee st. - the
Mills' neighbor Mr Smith's
carriage awaited me -
- at 4.20 - the friends
assembled at the house
Rev [Culthrop ?], [?] - &
two more friends - Miss Emily
Howland & self spoke -
- both Miss H & self spent
the night - the body of
C. D. B. Mills - was on the
sofa in his library - at 10
P.M. the undertaker put it
casket & carried to his room -
- all was done very quietly -
After supper - I
called on dear Mrs Phillips
- the sister of my best
friend of Ann Arbor - Mrs Hott
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Syracuse and attended the funeral of C.D.B. Mills. She spent the night at the house and called on Mrs. Phillips after supper.

entries.fullText:
Dr William Metts - [?]
son - left at 7:20 - for
Utica & Waterville - with
the casket - to have the body
cremated at Waterville -
Mrs Howland & self
left at 11. A,M, She for
Auburn & I for Rochester
direct -
entries.summaryText: Dr. William Metts and Susan B. Anthony's friend, Mrs. Howland, left to take care of C.D.B. Mills' body. Mrs. Howland went to Auburn and Susan went to Rochester.

entries.fullText:
At home
In the P.M. nephew
Frank M. Mosher &
wife Ella Dix called
to say a telegram from
Wendell P. Mosher bade them
take to nights train for
home - Duluth - Minn
Frank seemed very
much excited - was
quite sure I must have
written in to send the order
entries.summaryText: Frank M. Mosher & wife Ella Dix called to say a telegram from Wendell P. Mosher bade them take to nights train for home - Duluth - Minn. Frank seemed very much excited.

entries.fullText: Went to church - Ms. Harper also
entries.summaryText: Went to church with Ms. Harper.

entries.fullText:
at home
having a time getting
nerves of the upper
back teeth on left side
killed - so that the
place wouldn't cause
such pain
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home and describes having a difficult time with her teeth.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home.

entries.fullText: At home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote that she was at home on May 24, 1900.

entries.fullText:
6.25- but came to be 8. A.M.
Left Rochester — last! time
all the way over the Fitchburg
R.R. & reached Boston-
at 11. P.M. - & took cab to
Belvue Hotel- Beacon st.
next door to unitarian head
quarters- was soon in
bed in 372- 10th floor- this
day was fearfully hot- so
I missed even the very
last session of the 75th
anniversary of the Unitarian
Association in the U.S.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Rochester and traveled to Boston on May 25, 1900. She stayed at the Belvue Hotel and missed the last session of the 75th anniversary of the Unitarian Association due to the hot weather.

entries.fullText:
In Boston- at the Belmore-
called at Woman’s
Journal office- got
H.D.B. To cash a $50
check for me- met Alice & clerks- & at
the door met Frank Garrison, Wm Clark
husband of Helen Bright -
& accepted offer to go to the
Vendome at 1 P.M. to
New England women’s club
banquet in honor of Julia
Ward Howe- very nice- &
after it went to Dorchester
with H.D.B. & his Alice and
spent the night - a good
deal of careful talk
our new President & her
work before us-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a banquet in honor of Julia Ward Howe and spends the night in Dorchester with H.D.B. and Alice, discussing the new President and her work.

entries.fullText:
H.D.B. his Alice and their
clerk Miss Wilde- & self
drove from Dorchester to
1737- Beacon at- Brookline-
to Wm and Ellen Wright Garrisons
to dinner-Mr. Mrs. and Miss
William- Helen Bright, and
Alice Clark were there- &
after a while in came
our Rev Anna Shaw, who
had arrived at Belmore - gone
thence to Dorchester and thence to
Brookline - at 5 P.M. all
of us went to West Radford
took coffee - at Richard & Anna
David Hallowells = & at 9
returned - Miss Shaw & self to
the Belmore - & the rest back
to Brookline - it made
a most enjoyable time
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony has dinner with H.D.B., Alice, and others at the Wright Garrisons' in Brookline, and later takes coffee at West Radford with Rev Anna Shaw, Richard, and David Hallowells.

entries.fullText:
At the Bellevue -
Mrs Shean went 6 [?] - Cape Cod
New England annual meeting
at 9 Park Street at 2.20 -
- Mrs Howe presiding - &
re-elected for the 34th time
At 8. meeting in
[?] at Park st.
Church - no annual
of Mrs Catt - & no word
Rev Anna Garlin
Spencer was with me
at [?] & dinner
at the hotel -
entries.summaryText: Annual meeting in New England, Mrs. Howe re-elected for the 34th time, Mrs. Catt not present, Rev Anna Garlin Spencer was with me.

entries.fullText:
At Bellevue
At noon Miss Shaw &
niece Lucy E. arrived -
also Sarah J. Eddy - her
sister Amy - & Mrs [?]
of Providence -
Mrs Catt arrived this A.M.,
with her husband and went
to Journeys Hotel - so
she was on hand for the
Festival in Fanneul Hall -
this evening - it was really
quite the [?] also time
wide awake meeting -
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw, Lucy E., Sarah J. Eddy, her sister Amy, and Mrs. [?] of Providence arrived at Bellevue. Mrs. Catt arrived with her husband and went to Journeys Hotel. Festival in Fanneul Hall this evening, quite the [?], also time wide awake meeting.

entries.fullText:
Took breakfast with
Mrs Sarah Eddy & Co - -
Mrs Catt called just
before we left - Shaw
Lucy & self took the 1.05
train for West [Barnstable?]
- & reached [?] about
5 Oclock - it was lovely
& so cool that Anna
brought in the sticks,
bricks & made a blazing
fire on the hearth -
Mildred Conway Sawyer
daughter of Moncure Conway
lives here -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took breakfast with Mrs Sarah Eddy & Co and Mrs Catt called. She then traveled to West [Barnstable?] and arrived around 5 O'clock. She spent time with Mildred Conway Sawyer, daughter of Moncure Conway.

entries.fullText:
At [Weams ?] - Cape Cod -
& Miss Shaws College
the Haven - we two
walked the shore of
old ocean saw the
cottages of M.D. Conway -
Mrs. Chase, Ms Dietrich,
Mrs Osborn, the Garrisons
&c & - These homes used
to be lovely centres of reformers
- but are now rented or sold
to strangers - After
driver had Sallys horse & carriage
& drove through Osterville &
Centerville - called at the
beautiful home of R.
Marston - but couldn't get
report from anyone -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visited Cape Cod and Miss Shaws College. She walked along the shore and saw the cottages of M.D. Conway, Mrs. Chase, Ms Dietrich, Mrs Osborn, the Garrisons, and others. She also visited the beautiful home of R. Marston but couldn't get a report from anyone.

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText:
at home [underlined]
Sister Mary Luther Anthony
left for Des Moines this A.M.
at 8 oclock - brother Merritt
got her breakfast & made her
a cup of coffee & drove her
to the depot - their last look
at each other - was there -
Brother Merritt did
not work this day - he
felt too tired - he told the
Clyde Brown - but -
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary Luther Anthony left for Des Moines and Merritt drove her to the depot.

entries.fullText:
At home [underlined]
Brother Merritt vixed
the fence corner wall - on
the street - it was torn away -
entries.summaryText: Merritt fixed the fence corner wall on the street.

entries.fullText:
At home

brother Merritt dropped
dead - this night - 8.30 -
just opposite old stone - on wall
street - they telegraphed
brother D.R. at 11 - Oclock -
he telegraphed back to good Landen
take best care of body - till he
came - which would be first [thing ?]
on the morn - [?] [?]
at 1.50 - P.M. D.R. telegraphed
us - Mary & Susan - got it at
[?]. A.M. Friday -
entries.summaryText: Brother Merritt died suddenly at home and his body was taken care of by his brother D.R.

entries.fullText:
at home
got telegram at 3 A.M.
that brother Merritt dropped
dead at 8.30 Oclock least
night -. I couldn't go
to sleep again - It seemed so
dreadful - his wife Mary Luther
had left the Tuesday before [inserted - A.M.] 3 oclock.
Had several telegrams
from Brother D.R. after he
arrived at Fort Scott at 1.30 P.M.
- he told us he would attend
to everything - it would be the last
time I could go & do - so
at 9 P.M. I started - went to
Buffalo & took a fast train on
the [?] R.R. - got another
telegram after I was on board
of Sleeper - saying don't come -
but on I went -
entries.summaryText: Susan receives news of her brother Merritt's death and travels to attend to the arrangements.

entries.fullText: All this day I was travelling across [?], Illinois & Wisconsin - & at 10 Oclock, evening, arrived at Kansas [Pit?] - it was fearfully hot - I didn't know whether to go to Fort Scott at 10.15 or to Leavenworth at samn hour, but had to decide quickly - & went to Leavenworth - Sister Anne came down & let me in - I found the funeral was going to be at 12 noon tomorrow - I was sorry I didn't go to Fort Scott but there was nothing to be done but to wait - Mary Luther & Maria Luther Walker arrived at Fort Scott at 1.30 this noon - It was fearful that Mary was gone for California - she was at her cousin Ruth - Desmond - [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels across Illinois and Wisconsin to arrive in Kansas Pit. She decides to go to Leavenworth instead of Fort Scott. She attends a funeral the next day.

entries.fullText: At Leavenworth Kan - The day was long - but fearfully hot - I was in spirit with them at Fort Scott - but at 6.30 - the train arrived & brother D.R. came of train alone - the hearse was ready - & Mr Page - who had been with us at Sister [?] death - little amenities - & dear niece Susie B.'s - went with us to Mount [Muncie ?] - it was beautiful there - & as we laid the dear body of mothers darling baby to rest - he was 66. the 19th of April - the moon shone down upon us so calmly & serenely - well - it was heart breaking - to feel that the poor boy's heart never found any rest or peace - but his long unrest was over - Has he joined dear mother & father are they all waiting the coming of those left behind -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a funeral in Leavenworth and visits Mount Muncie. She reflects on the deceased's life and wonders if they have joined their loved ones.

entries.fullText:
Nephew Burt was
on train going into Fort
Scott - yesterday noon -
as Brother D.A. & the body
of dear Merritt were on the
the train going north
to Leavenworth - so
Burt did not get
home in time for the
funeral - The old soldiers of
whom he was one - attended the funeral
in a body - But the
funeral was a lovely
tribute to brother Merritt's
life.- Rev Mr Porter
officiated - he had lived
there almost as long as
brother - they had worked
together in enforcing Prohibition law
entries.summaryText: Nephew Burt missed the funeral of Merritt due to a train delay, but the funeral was a lovely tribute to Merritt's life.

entries.fullText:
I went to Fort Scott
this day - it was
a sad journey - no
brother Merritt met me
at the Junction - he
nearly always hitched
his horse at Depot - and
rode out on train to
the junction - to meet me -
It was a sad house -
Poor May Suther - she
looked like despair - but
it is all over - & no
change can now be
made - Her sister Maria
Luther Walker - & nephew Richard
Luther Anthony - there with her-
she looked broken down with -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Fort Scott and met with May Suther and her family after the funeral of Merritt.

entries.fullText: Ther. fearfully hot weather
entries.summaryText: Hot weather in Fort Scott on June 13, 1900.
No entry written on June 14, 1900 in Fort Scott.

entries.fullText:
Wea. FRI. JUNE 15, 1900 Ther.
at Fort Scott
entries.summaryText: Journal entry written on June 15, 1900 in Fort Scott.

entries.fullText:
Wea. SAT. JUNE 16, 1900 Ther.
at Fort Scott
entries.summaryText: Journal entry written on June 16, 1900 in Fort Scott.

entries.fullText:
at Brother Merritts home !!
The rain came down splendidly
and his visible presence
gone out from it forever -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about being at Brother Merritt's home in Fort Scott, Kansas and how the rain came down splendidly.

entries.fullText:
Drove with S.J. Chapin to see
house north of Wall Street lots
- to exchange for Mapleton 85 acres -
then to Crawford at. Mr
Replinger - talk buying 3 houses
In P.M. took long &
last drive after Merritts
ponies - with Burt - drove
through Mo. Pacific work shops -
took a drink of Sulphur water
at Mo. Pacific pavilions at
Station - then drove south
and to look at the lots - &
then home - and what a sad
home - Merritt gone - all is
gone - I shall hardly ever want
to go to Fort Scott - again
Brother Merritt is buried at
Leavenworth - so now all we
have in Kansas is there - Brother
Dan's Cemetery lot - now contains
Sister Hannah & brother Merritt -
Little Annette & Susie B. -
who will go there next?!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day in Fort Scott, Kansas, where she drove with S.J. Chapin to see a house north of Wall Street lots and to Crawford at Mr. Replinger to talk about buying 3 houses. She also took a long drive after Merritt's ponies and visited Mo. Pacific work shops and pavilions.

entries.fullText:
Burt drove me to see Mrs
Parker about buying house - &
left me at Dr [?] - of
whom brother Merritt got
medicine the [?] before his death -
there [?] to the Dr. that there
was something the matter with
his heart- My first thought
on waking was I have slept
on the same mattress that
dear brother slept on & laid awake
upon the last two nights after
his Mary L. left for Des Moines - I
wrote in set of Revolutions
for Burt & History of W.S.
for Y.M.C.A. Library - &
another set for May S. to
present to new city Library -
Left Fort Scott at 1.50 - &
rode after Merritts ponies in old
machine wagon - with Burt - &
landed Leavenworth at 6.45 - &
found sister Annie not done
supper - brother Dan on
the porch - glad to see me
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about visiting Mrs. Parker to buy a house, seeing Dr. [?], writing for the Y.M.C.A. Library, and traveling to Leavenworth to visit family.

entries.fullText:
At Leavenworth -
got up at 6 - wrote
letter to sister Mary L. -
& had Jackson take it
to post office before breakfast -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about writing a letter to her sister Mary L. and having Jackson take it to the post office before breakfast.

entries.fullText:
At brother Daniel R's 0
Leavenworth - Kanses -
a two weeks ago to day
[?] dear brother Merritt's
last in the earthly form -
- though I had a lovely
drive out - Cherokee street
with Sister Anna - & though
I have talked & eaten breakfast
& dinner & shall supper as of
[?] - my thought is ever
upon mother's darling boy - never
more to be seen by us - whither
has his immortal past gone - is it still
with an immortal past - & me
not capable of feeling & knowing its
presence -

And [?] as the
[?] say - "Mine eyes were
a fountain of tears" - It seemed
impossible for me to do anything
but weep - while I was
at Fort Scott - I shed many
tears than in years & years
before - I thought I was
done with tears; but no!!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to brother Daniel R's in Leavenworth, Kansas, where she talks about her deceased brother Merritt and sheds tears while visiting Fort Scott.

entries.fullText:
In Leavenworth
at Brother Daniel R.'s
Nephew Burt Luther A.
came at 6.45 - nephew
D.R. & wife Bessie came to
supper with us -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Brother Daniel R.'s in Leavenworth, where she has supper with nephew Burt Luther A., and Brother Daniel R. and his wife Bessie.

entries.fullText:
In forenoon Sister
Anna took nephew Burt
L & me out to St, [Burnice ?]
there to see the not yet two
weeks [prev. two words underline] old mound that covers
the dear form of brother Merritt
- all seemed peaceful but
oh the longing for one look - one
sound of his voice once more -
- but all is over - there we
must leave him
Daniel & Bessie took
dinner with us - & at 5 P.M.
Brother Dan & Sister Anna went
to Depot - the Burlington - with us
also nephew D.R. - and were
off for St Jo - Brother Dan. crossed
the River with us - & as he
stood on the track watching
the train & waving his hat to us -
his cheeks were as pink & white
as ever were dear mothers - he
is to be 76 on Aug 22. - Burt
& I ate our nice lunch &
after reading I went to bed
entries.summaryText: Sister Anna, nephew Burt L, and I visited the mound that covers the grave of brother Merritt. Daniel, Bessie, and nephew D.R. had dinner with us. Brother Dan and Sister Anna left for St Jo with us. Burt and I ate lunch and I went to bed.

entries.fullText:
We reached Chicago - 8.20
this morning - Mrs Gross met us
at Union Station - & had breakfast
waiting - - Mr Gross gave us a
warm welcome - during the
forenoon took Burt over to
Mrs Coonleys - dear Sarah
came down & sang for us -
- - After dinner Dr Frances
Dickenson her Dr Lohdell, Mr
Colby & mrs C.C. Bradford called
- later Burt & self took supper
with Melissa & Albert Dickenson
& at 9 P.M. Mrs Gross came
& took us to the [?] at
Station - where we took the
Nickel Plate train for Rochester
& left at 11 Oclock
Two weeks ago - as the
sun had set - and the moon
was nearly overhead - we laid brother
Merritt to rest in Mount [?] -
his daughters - Lucy E. & Anna &
eldest son Daniel Jr. - not there - but
his youngest boy Burt was
entries.summaryText: We arrived in Chicago and were greeted by Mrs Gross. We had breakfast and Burt visited Mrs Coonleys. Dr Frances Dickenson, Dr Lohdell, Mr Colby, and Mrs C.C. Bradford visited us. We had supper with Melissa and Albert Dickenson. Mrs Gross took us to the station where we left for Rochester. Brother Merritt was laid to rest two weeks ago.

entries.fullText: Burt Luther Anthony & I travelled all the day on Nikel Plate R.R., and at Buffalo - he took the Penn. R.R. to Boston - & I came on to Rochester reaching home at 8.21 - and here ended the fearful journey - Burt is a nice boy - He had to hurry back to his Post or else go over his two weeks furlough - Found Sister Mary well - Anna E Dann also
entries.summaryText: Burt Luther Anthony and Susan B. Anthony travelled by train from Nikel Plate R.R. to Buffalo, where Burt took the Penn. R.R. to Boston and Susan continued on to Rochester. They arrived at 8:21 PM. Susan mentions that Burt is a nice boy and that she found Sister Mary and Anna E Dann well.
Susan B. Anthony was at home on June 26, 1900.

entries.fullText:
Wea. WED. JUNE 27, 1900
at Home
entries.summaryText: Journal entry dated June 27, 1900, written at home.

entries.fullText:
Wea. THUR. JUNE 28, 1900 Ther.
at Home
entries.summaryText: Journal entry dated June 28, 1900, written at home.

entries.fullText:
I left Rochester
on P.M. trrain - for
Auburn - Mrs Osborne
met me at station -
This was hardly a rest
from the long journey
& the trying times -
to [Ronson ?] & return
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Rochester for Auburn and met with Mrs. Osborne.

entries.fullText:
A pic-nic at
the lake-side some
8 or 10 miles from
Auburn - Mrs Osborne
& Miss Emily Howland
took me out - a terrible
wind came up & blew
down their stand -
& the men fixed another
but it was cold - I
made my speech - & went
back home to supper &
went to bed - all night
so far as I knew
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a picnic at the lake-side with Mrs. Osborne and Miss Emily Howland and made a speech.

entries.fullText:
- Undertook to take bath
- when a stitch took
me in the back - that
made me faint - but
staggered back to bed -
- It was the tightest
sort of a grab - I could [words crossed out here]
move neither hand nor
foot but with excessive
pain - - by afternoon Mrs O.
called Dr Woodruff - to
give electric treatment -
& then called a trained
nurse - Miss Mary [Buineen ?]
of NO. 3. Washington Street -
- so that her mind would
be perfectly freed from care -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a medical emergency while taking a bath at Mrs. Osborn's house. Mrs. Osborn called Dr. Woodruff and a trained nurse, Miss Mary [Buineen ?], to take care of her.

entries.fullText:
- could get in no easy
position -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Auburn and had difficulty finding a comfortable position.

entries.fullText:
at Auburn
with Doctors
applying electricity
and giving me some
awful medicine [underlined]
Old school - he
said it was a tired
out body [previous three words underlined]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at Auburn with doctors who are applying electricity and giving her medicine. The doctor says her body is tired out.

entries.fullText:
At Mrs Osborns
A little better -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at Mrs. Osborn's and feeling a little better.

entries.fullText:
Anna Shaw - &
niece Susy E. Anthony
came to Mrs Osborns
& I cam home
with them
entries.summaryText: Anna Shaw and Susan B. Anthony's niece, Susy E. Anthony, visited Mrs. Osborn's and Susan B. Anthony went home with them.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry for this date.

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText:
At home
Mrs Frank Esterbrook of
Brooklyn, her mother & cousin
& Samuel Clark - called -
Receipts came from the
Bowen Merrill Co - for balance
on Life & Work purchased of them
$155 - which added to the $250
royalty received from them - makes
$405 - that I have paid them
for setts to give - which they
let me half-price - [previous two words underlined]
Also receipt for $269.45
my half of payment for all of
the remaining books - over 1000 of
[?] [?] & over 900 bound sets -

[Lucy? or Suzy ?] E. Left for Phila
to attend wedding of Anna [?.]
Anthony & Leon Brooks Bacon
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives receipts from Bowen Merrill Co. and Mrs. Frank Esterbrook of Brooklyn visits her at home. Lucy E. leaves for Philadelphia to attend the wedding of Anna Anthony and Leon Brooks Bacon.

entries.fullText:
at home
Niece Anna O. Anthony
&
Leon Brooks Baker [Bacon is written above the Baker name]
niece married at noon - today - at
home of dear niece H. Louise
Mosher James - 4716 [?] St
Philadelphia - niece Lucy E. & nephew
Burt Luther Anthony - both there -
Sister Mary & I decided it was to long &
too expensive & too hot a journey - so
sent our letters & little tokens -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's niece, Anna O. Anthony, marries Leon Brooks Baker in Philadelphia. Susan and her sister Mary do not attend the wedding due to the long and expensive journey.

entries.fullText: 80th birthday celebration [name Brook is crossed out] Death of Merritt Marriage Anna Girls Admitted to B.U. Illinois many visitors Put in new water pips & plumbing while sisters away
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her 80th birthday celebration, the death of Merritt, the marriage of Anna, girls being admitted to B.U., visitors, and plumbing work being done.

entries.fullText: [?] barely mentions wonderful [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about something that is barely mentioned and something wonderful.

entries.fullText: [this line and next unreadable]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about an unreadable line.

entries.fullText: Su Oct 29
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about October 29th.

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText:
At home - After
breakfast - read paper - then
started for attic to arrange
newspaper clippings for Scrap - books
- stopped at desk & wrote letter
of sympathy to Miss
Mary J. Lathrop - 37 Park Place -
Buffalo N.Y. the only survivor of
the three noble women who made
[?] home - Nov. 25, 1892 - when
I was guest there - to speak at
the old Female Academy Alumnae
meeting - of which Mrs Charlotte
Mulligan was President - Mrs.
died recently (Lathrop)
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day at home, arranging newspaper clippings and writing a letter of sympathy to Mary J. Lathrop, the only survivor of three women who made a home where Anthony was a guest in 1892. She also mentions Mrs. Charlotte Mulligan, who recently passed away.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry for this date

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText:
Ther.
at home -
working on newspaper clippings
with A.C.D. & Mrs. Hawley -
Letter from brother D.R.
saying he & sister Anna would
leave Leavenworth Wed. Aug. 1. 5.35 -
[word crossed out] Chicao 9.45 - Aug 2. - go through
Rochester 3 A.M. the 3rd Albany
9.05 - Boston 4 P.M. and
land in Edgartown 7 P.M. the 3rd
about 50 hours - [rapid ?] trip -
How it reminds me that dear
brother Merritt will never tell
us he is coming & 3 years ago
now he & brother D.R. sister
Mary & I were at Adams together -
Visited Battenville & took dinner
with dear[Candace ?] Hyatt &
her Sarah Elizia & Edgar - all gone
now! 'Darling boy" - our dear
mother used to call him - does
she see him over there!!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about receiving a letter from her brother D.R. and sister Anna, who are traveling from Leavenworth to Edgartown, and reflects on the memories of her family and friends who have passed away.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry for this date.

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText:
At Home -
suggest - at Dr Regna's
at 3 P.M. or later - Dr
too busy & weather too hot --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony suggests meeting with Dr. Regna at her home but he is too busy and the weather is too hot.

entries.dateText: Wea. TUES. AUG. 7, 1900 Ther. [handwritten 95 next to Ther.]
entries.fullText:
at home
Went to Dr Regna's this
forenoon - decided to
tinker away with old
plate yet awhile -
if it can be made to fit
better & not interfere with
accenting the consonants so much
- after leaving - went to
Maddbury Grocery just east - &
[?] - bought basket of
Cling stone, home grown
peaches - took out of pocket
red womans wallet that carry
bills in - handed girl a $10 bill
- just [?] 2.50 into purse - & the
5 & 2 dollar bills into wallet
replaced it in left dress pocket -
grenadine - so probably didn't
do it - but - let it slip to floor -
at any rate never thought of it
again until next day - & so it
couldn't be found - there were
just $17. in it - gave look [?]
- name & address were clear if
written on it
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony goes to Dr. Regna's and then to Maddbury Grocery to buy peaches. She loses her wallet with $17 in it.

entries.fullText: Went for my red[?] wallet & lo it wasn't to be found - at last it occurred to me that I had lost it yesterday - telephoned to [?] etc - but got no tidings - it worries me - to be so careless - as well as to have thrown away $17 - Luckily I had been to the bank - & deposited $50 - I had in it - so that was saved - The weather is hotter if possible to day Found the wallet at home - just where I put it
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about losing her wallet and finding it again at home.

entries.fullText: Spent the last two days reading over letters that contained money - 1st for standing fund - 2nd for Birth day presents & 3rd for Life memberships - & believe everything is now strait - formed out two missions to nightly record everything which was pretty well for the hurry & bustle of Washington & civil service -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about reading letters containing money and organizing her finances while in Washington.

entries.fullText:
at home
had to bring papers
down - the [attic ?]
was too powerful hot
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home and had to bring papers down from the attic due to the heat.

entries.fullText:
at home -
For the 2.21 train
Anna [?] went with
Lucy E. to Station - & had
to walk from corners on
account of fire in Barnards
Paint Store - corner of East Illinois
& Aqueduct streets - down [?]
State in the terrific heat - at
last were overtaken by a
Car on Central avenue bridge
Lucy E. joined Miss Shaw
on train & they together went
to Lily Dale Camp meeting
where Miss Shaw is to speak
Sunday - Tuesday & Wednesday -
then go west to Humbold farm
& on & on - & get back here the [?]
Lucy E. is to return here on
Thursday -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed at home and later accompanied Anna and Lucy E. to the station. They had to walk due to a fire and the heat. Lucy E. joined Miss Shaw to attend the Lily Dale Camp meeting where Miss Shaw is to speak on Sunday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Lucy E. is to return on Thursday.

entries.fullText:
-
weather fairly cold -
a wonderful change
from the first [?]
& from yesterday P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about the weather being cold at home.

entries.fullText:
-
a nice steady - all day
rain - all three
of us - Hawley & Darin
& self working in the
[?] on scrap books
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about working on scrapbooks with Hawley and Darin while it rained all day.

entries.fullText:
at home -
Rained all the forenoon
but cleared off so that
[?] put out & got
her clothes dried -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about being at home on August 14, 1900. She mentioned that it rained all morning but cleared up later, allowing someone to put out and dry their clothes.

entries.fullText:
At home
Comfortable weather
niece Anna O. called
seemed very happy -
entries.summaryText: On August 15, 1900, Susan B. Anthony wrote about being at home and receiving a visit from her niece Anna O., who seemed very happy.

entries.fullText:
At home
back from Lily [?]
Niece Lucy E. came at
2.30. P.M. - Mrs Mary
Seymour Harwell came
about 10 - stayed to lunch &
took the 4. P.M. train for
Mt. Morris - she brot her mother
to station to join her brother
to make a trip east - we
had a very pleasant visit -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about visitors at her home, including Lucy E. and Mrs. Mary Seymour Harwell, who came to visit before leaving for a trip to Mt. Morris.

entries.fullText:
At home
at work on scraps
for Mrs Stantons book -
Both Miss Hawley &
Anna E. Dann at work on
1899 clippings - the first
sorting & piecing together the
latter pasting into the book -

Banked our Life
Membership Certificates -
all - some 20 - write me
back they have never
had Certificates sent
them - just as I feared -
[?] had been doing -
so now I am making
them out - ready to mail
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about working on Mrs. Stanton's book and banking Life Membership Certificates.

people: Mrs. Rate Trimble de Roode Woolsey
entries.fullText: By 10 Oclock - Mrs. Rate Trimble de Roode Woolsey - daughter of Judge W.M. Trimble at Covington - [?] where I have been guest several times since 1880 - came - they came on night train from N. [Jersey ?] breakfasted & at Powers Hotel - to read to me an address which she proposes to publish in London - showing that Republics degrade women below the status of aristocracies & [?] - It is a great satire on Equality of rights theories - weather hot - out of [?] & in the attic but comfortable in lower part of house
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Rate Trimble de Roode Woolsey visits Susan B. Anthony at her home and reads an address she plans to publish in London about how Republics degrade women below the status of aristocracies.

entries.fullText: Wea. TUES. AUG. 28, 1900 Ther.

The [B?].C. came
this day
entries.summaryText: The [B?].C. came this day

entries.fullText:
The Business Committee
met here-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about the Business Committee meeting on August 30, 1900.

entries.fullText:
Executive Committee
here -
Had to supper
Mrs. Greenleaf - Mrs. Coonley -
with the whole nine
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about the Executive Committee meeting on August 31, 1900 and having supper with Mrs. Greenleaf and Mrs. Coonley.

entries.fullText:
Left Rochester. 4.20
for Wyoming - on Mrs
Coonley-Wards - Milleage
book - nine [underlined] of us -
Anthony - Blackwell
Shaw Clay
Foster Ivey [?] McCullough
Upton - Chapman Catt
and Lizzie
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Rochester with a group of people, including Mrs. Coonley-Wards, to go to Wyoming.

entries.fullText: At Wyoming
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Wyoming.

entries.fullText:
Miss Shaw drove over
to Warsaw to take
train this P.M. - which
left only [?] - Blackwell -
McCullock, Upton &
Anthony + Missy
Foster, Catt & Shaw - gone -
Had a good meeting
spite of tremendous thunder
shower just at gathering
time -
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw drove to Warsaw to take a train, leaving several people behind. Despite a thunder shower, they had a good meeting.

entries.fullText:
Left Wyoming at 7.35 - A.M.
- Upton, Blackwell, [?], Clay
McCuloch - all scattered -
The last went to the Falls - B. to
Geneva - W & H. to Rochester - Upton
Sister Mary to Greenleaf's - then
back to dinner - then to Auburn.
Mis Ransen and her Lucy
went downtown & bought
Geneva tea-spoons - one
for each of the new members
of B.C. who were present -
entries.summaryText: Several people left Wyoming and scattered to different locations. Mis Ransen and Lucy bought Geneva tea-spoons for new members of B.C.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry written on September 5, 1900

entries.fullText: This was last day that [?] was with us - she left on 5 P.M. train for Boston - a&ll alone now - A telegram from W. P. Mosher saying don't talk with Frank [?] - [?] had arrived at six first of week - & we had not know it - He had left Wendell without learning we are left alone Lucy gone
entries.summaryText: Someone left on September 6, 1900 and a telegram was received from W. P. Mosher regarding Frank. It was also mentioned that someone had arrived in Wendell without them knowing and that Lucy is gone.

entries.fullText:
[This entire page is written with the page turned from vertical to horizontal so that the writing starts at fold of book and runs toward the left side of the page]

Valley [?] - called out Sam [?]
I went in & he guaranteed [$2,000 or $2500] - then
I drove to 11.40 Granite Building - & after
long waiting - the Trustees - Mrs Montgomery &
Mrs [?] came - Mrs. M. told them Miss
Anthony had a report to make - they had
not expected it - then they waited & queried - and
then they asked if the persons had legally qualified. [last two words double underlined]
I then told them the truth that Mr W had given
me permit [underlined] to use his name [last three words underlined] - that I stood
sponsor for the 2500 - & would give them the
collaterals & money A.M. - a Com. was appointed - to meet Monday -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met with Sam and Mrs. Montgomery and then with the Trustees at 11.40 Granite Building. She explained that Mr. W had given her permission to use his name and that she would sponsor the $2,500.

entries.fullText:
Ther.
Mrs Bigelow came to
talk to me about Fund - 1,000
dollars were lacking - she sent for
carriage & I, with her, started out
- called at Sarah L. Willis - got
her $2,000 - scholarship to put with
Sister Marys $2,000 scholarship -
which made one half - then drove to
[three words crossed out] to John [Daleys's ?], then
to Mr Eastman's - flat refused but
he is doing good work with [?] above
at Mechanics Institute then I told him of
every scheme of the flats-only building
not belonging to the institute - buy that & make
it a training school for domestics -
then all employers agree not to
take a girl without a certificate [?]
- the idea struck him - then home to dinner - carriage again at 1.30 - then
drove to W.R. Morse - then to Woolworth
then Mrs Fitzsimons - then to the Sibley's
then to Wilders - Clara drove with me
to Granger Hollisters not at home - We
went to Mr Gannetts, he guaranteed
[?] 500 - & another 1000 - making
$1,500 - then drove to Genessee
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met with Mrs. Bigelow to discuss a fund and went to various locations to collect money. She also proposed an idea to Mr. Eastman about creating a training school for domestics and received a guarantee of $1,500 from Mr. Gannetts.

entries.fullText:
Valley Club - called out Sam [?]
I went in & he guaranteed $2000 - then
I drove to 11.40 Granite Building - & after
long waiting - the Trustees - Mrs Montgomery &
Mrs [?] came - Mrs. M. told them Miss
Anthony had a report to make - they had
not expected it - then they waited & queried - and
then they asked if the persons had legally qualified. [last two words double underlined]
I then told them the truth that Mr M [?] had given
me permit [underlined] to use his name [last three words underlined] - that I stood
sponsor for the 2500 - & would give them the
collaterals & money A.M. - a Com. was appointed - to meet Monday
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with Sam and drives to 11.40 Granite Building to meet with Trustees about a report she has to make. She explains that Mr. M gave her permission to use his name and that she will give them the collaterals and money in the morning.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Bigelow came to
talk to me about Funds - 1,000
dollars were lacking - she sent for
carriage & I, with her, started out
- called at Sarah L. Willis - got
her $2,000 - scholarship - to put with
sister Marys $2,000 scholarship -
which made one half - then drove to
[three words crossed out] to John [Fahey's ?], then
to Mrs Eastman's - flat refused but
he is doing good work with 2 above
at Mechanics Institute - then I told him of
my scheme of the flats - only building
not belonging to the institute - buy that & make
it a training school for domestics
then all employers agree not to
take a girl without a certificate [?]
- the idea struck him - then home
to dinner - carriage again at 1.30 then
drove to W.R. Morse - then to Woolworth
then Mrs Fitzsimons - then to the Sibley &
then to Wilders - Clara drove with me
to Granger Hollister's - not at home. We
went to Mr. Gannetts, he guaranteed
[?] 500 - & another 1000 - making
$1,500 - then drove to Gennessee
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with Mrs. Bigelow to discuss funds and they go on a trip to collect scholarships and donations. She also proposes a scheme to create a training school for domestics and meets with Mr. Gannetts who guarantees $1,500.

entries.fullText: Went to Church - had a sleepy time - had a sleepy time - seems as if something the matter with my tongue - had a feeling of strangeness - could not think of what I wanted to say - a queer sensation - al the afternoon - Mary asked me if my teeth were out - shall be better or move to- morrow!! Wendell was to have some letter here - he telegraphed the 6th - see letter!! - Wendell - at last wrote - Frank has been told he wasn't wanted
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to church and felt strange, had a sleepy time and a feeling of strangeness. Mary asked about her teeth. Wendell wrote a letter and Frank was told he wasn't wanted.

entries.fullText: Monday - felt queer but went to Mr Williams office - said he was ordered to go through all the pledges & see if they were good - I went home disgusted - he [?] on ly at my pledge of $2,000 - - well they let the girls in Said there was no alternative - At night - 1.8 girls called - who were going to the College - a fine lot - I felt so strange - couldn't talk to the girls - at last went off to bed - called Dr Sherman Ricker - she said it was "Fogg" - was tired out !! But I fear it was more Brother Daniel R. & Sister Anna arrive at 10 Oclock - I did not see them this night
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Mr. Williams' office and felt disgusted. She couldn't talk to the girls who called at night and felt strange. She called Dr. Sherman Ricker and Brother Daniel R. & Sister Anna arrived.

entries.fullText:
The Dr. came
this morning & again
& again for a whole
month every day - [this entire line underlined]

Brother D.R. & Anna - his
wife - visiting us I staid
in bed in the west chamber
entries.summaryText: The Dr. came to visit every day for a month. Brother D.R. and Anna visited and the author stayed in bed in the west chamber.

entries.fullText:
In bed -
Brother D.R. & Sister Anna
entries.summaryText: Brother D.R. and Sister Anna visited while the author was in bed.

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText:
Brother D.R. & sister
Anna left for home this
day -

I am better
but far from myself
entries.summaryText: Brother D.R. and sister Anna left for home. The author is feeling better but not quite herself.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry for this date.

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText:
Daniel S. Reed - passed to
the unknown - this afternoon -
so goes the only son of [?]
Joshua Reed - he was 76 - being
[?] born May 29, 1824 - he was
a little older than brother Daniel
- who was born august. 22. 1824 -
he has been ill for several
years - last one - Demented -
almost wholly - [?] Sarah - she
has had a fearful time -
she has been faithful to the end
entries.summaryText: Daniel S. Reed passed away and Susan B. Anthony reflects on his life and the impact on his family.

entries.fullText: Ther. at home Mrs Emily Ward Gross (S.E.) arrived at [7.20 ?] - oclock A.M. Niece Anna A. went to meet her - Sister Mary hard at work on her program for next year - Mrs G. & Mary, & Anna Dann went driving - through the university grounds - as I drove over the Campus - I felt "these are not forbidden grounds to the girls of the city any longer" - It is good to feel that the old doors swing on their hinges to women: will the vows be kept to them - that the girls have equal chance with the boys - They promise well - the fulfillment will be seen - whether there shall not be some hitch - between - proposed a separate school - then girls take first place - Mrs [?] of Macedon - at front - She was John Lapham's grand daughter
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Mrs. Emily Ward Gross arriving at her home and going driving through the university grounds. She reflects on the opportunities for women and the possibility of a separate school for girls.

entries.fullText: Ther. This forenoon - went to Genessee Lake- & the farm - the weather is lovely - Mary gone to [?] to P.C. Church meeting - left at 8.20 & stays until 7.20 Mrs Gross enjoying herself -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about going to Genessee Lake and the farm. She notes that Mary has gone to a P.C. Church meeting and Mrs. Gross is enjoying herself.

entries.fullText: Ther. at home Mrs Gross here - we took a drive - the Parks are beautiful
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a drive with Mrs. Gross and enjoyed the beautiful parks.

entries.fullText: Ther. at home A drive again - We drove out past a new saw Leon & Anna O. Anthony down street - took them in an drove to north Park Seneca - had a nice drive
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took another drive and met with Leon & Anna O. Anthony before enjoying a nice drive to north Park Seneca.

entries.fullText: Mrs Gross - got the fever to retrim my black satin waist - She tried very hard to get it down and be ready for the 5.30 train - but she could not - so decided to stay over another day - and took a drive instead - She is a trump
entries.summaryText: Mrs Gross got the fever to retrim Susan's black satin waist but could not finish it and decided to stay over another day.

entries.fullText: Mrs Gross - with niece Anna - worked on dress and got it done at 4 P.M. May & I [?] - took Mrs Gross to station - at 5.30 drove around & took Anna home - then I left May at station with Mrs. Gross - She is a lovely, sweet woman - her love for me surpasses all understanding -She presented me with a pair of slippers-gray - a little white knit cape - and an old fashioned white [?] shawl - deep border on it - it is a long - shawl very beautiful - It is beautiful it was her mothers
entries.summaryText: Susan spent time with Mrs Gross and her niece Anna, and helped them finish a dress. Mrs Gross gave Susan some gifts including a beautiful shawl that belonged to her mother.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Journal entry on October 3, 1900, written at home.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No journal entry on October 4, 1900.

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText:
At home [underlined]
The inaugural of Pre
Bush Rees - attended -
it was the first time
I had been out -
not a strait mention
of the girls - asked before
he said he [mentioned ?]
to [?] them as if they
had always been there
- well, if they had - they
would have deserved a
mention - but no matter
they are in - there is no
getting them out!!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended the inaugural of Pre Bush Rees and was disappointed that he did not mention the girls.

entries.fullText:
These days was
pledged to be at
[?] - [?] to
state convention - Could
not go - of course
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was unable to attend a state convention she was pledged to be at.

entries.fullText:
Pledged to be S. - the
[?] state meeting
at Roadhead - [?]
had to write them could
not go = - Was very sorry
to miss this Wisconsin
meeting -
entries.summaryText: Missed the Wisconsin meeting at Roadhead and had to write to them instead.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry for this date.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry for this date

entries.fullText:
Ohio State W.S. A. Meeting at
Athen - 18 & 19 - Did not
go - of course -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony did not attend the Ohio State W.S. A. Meeting in Athen on October 18 and 19.

entries.fullText:
Had Paynes carriages
for 11 - drives - he charged
$22.25 - Mrs Gross paid
$15 - leaving me 7.25 -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony used Paynes carriages for 11 drives and Mrs Gross paid $15 leaving her with $7.25.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry for this date.

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText:
[N.J. ?] State - W.S.L. and meeting
at Glens Falls - NY
Mary left at 6.42 - for Glens
Falls - Mrs Sanford, Mrs [Clark ?]
& others - I [re...?] to
put in new water
pipes - & new water
closet - to begin tomorrow
rain or shine -
entries.summaryText: Meeting in Glens Falls, NJ. Planning to put in new water pipes and closet.

entries.fullText:
The men began work
on Digging - to put in
new water pipes to the
street - they were laid nearly
30 years ago - the old iron
pipes - they were filled with
rust - -
entries.summaryText: Work began on putting in new water pipes to the street.

entries.fullText: To day came the new water closet [last two words underlined] promised - [Smiths & Oberst ?] to get it done to day - but could not do it so it went on till tomorrow The water [?] beautifully - I know they will be pleased though she wont say anything about it - brackets surround last four lines]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the installation of a new water closet that was promised to be done that day but was delayed until the next day.

entries.fullText: Sarah Burtiss - buried this A.M> - 9.45 - taken to Buffalo to be Cremated [underlined] Mille & husband went to Buffalo - It seems hardly 65 years since Sarah Anthony taught school for us children at Battenville - she was almost 90 - [?] [?] - had she lived till December 1 - a remarkable woman I rode to the house 96 Manhattan street - & to the depot with them - The men finished the closet to night - Mary returned from Glens Falls - at 10 - to night - got the closet & pipes all done -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the burial of Sarah Burtiss and reflects on her life. She also mentions her own activities, including riding to a house and a depot, and the completion of the water closet installation.

entries.fullText: [No entries for these dates]
entries.summaryText: No entries for these dates

entries.fullText:
Ther.
did not go to
Church - 8 weeks [underlined] to
day - since I discovered
any trouble with my
talking - it was at close
of church - I do not
get back my power
but am a good deal
better. -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony did not go to church due to trouble with her talking.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry for this date.

entries.fullText:
Helped Ana -
do the work - went
to bed in P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony helped Ana with work and went to bed in the afternoon.

entries.fullText:
[?] - so I
did go over to see
niece Anna - in
P.M. called on
Dr Moore - in P.M.
had a nice talk with
him - of the [?]
& of my attack - he
said absolutely nothing [underlined]
could be done [last 3 words underlined] - nature
must do the remedy
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visited her niece Anna and had a talk with Dr. Moore about her health, but he said nothing could be done and nature must take its course.

entries.fullText: Ther. at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a short entry stating that she was at home.

entries.fullText:
Ther. feeling better - but
cannot write any thoughts
as usual - -
snow
storm to day - for first
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote that she was feeling better but couldn't write any thoughts. She also noted that there was a snowstorm that day, the first of the season.

entries.fullText:
nine weeks to-day -
since I started out
to get the money - 8,000 - to
finish the 50,000 - for the
opening of the college doors
to girls - got it - by Mrs
Willis - giving $2,000 - Sister
Mary $2,000 - Mrs Gannett -
$1500 - with Mrs [G. ?] 500 - 2,000
and Mr [?] Wilder guar-
anteing the other $200 - My
last speech - was made
to the Ex. Com. of the Board
of Trustees - They refused to take
Mr. Wilders guarantee - - so I told [underlined]
them I was good for it [all underlined] &
- not a trustee [all underlined] - has given
anything - though there
are several millionaires among
them - Dr. Moor - afterward told
me he was ashamed [?]
Sister Mary had to come forward
with [?] of her hard earned money
[Note: all wording from 'anything - though there...' is in a large bracket]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about getting the money needed to open college doors to girls and her last speech to the Ex. Com. of the Board of Trustees.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry for this date.

entries.fullText:
at home
Snowy & blowy
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote on November 14, 1900 that she was at home and the weather was snowy and blowy.
Susan B. Anthony wrote on November 15, 1900 that she was at home and the weather was cold and blowy.

entries.fullText:
at home -
Entertainment at the U.
Church Parlors - Mabel Powers
to read - or recite -
Took a sleep after dinner
Rev Anna J. Shaw called
a moment - came from
Cobleskill - to Albany then on
Empire State - & stopped over
till slow train left -
Gave Anna E. Dann
recommend to Miss Smart [last two words underlined]
to go for a Trained Nurse [last two words underlined]
- - she is to commence
the middle of December - she
is too good a girl to lose,
but she will never be content
until she tries what it is to
be a "trained nurse" -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day at home and an entertainment at the U. Church Parlors. She mentions the visit of Rev Anna J. Shaw and her recommendation to Miss Smart to go for a Trained Nurse.

entries.fullText:
Anna Shaw
came in from
Batavia & spent-
[...day] with us -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the visit of Anna Shaw who came from Batavia and spent the day with them.

entries.fullText:
No going to Church
Anna Shaw with us
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony did not go to church and spent time with Anna Shaw.

entries.fullText:
Anna Shaw with us
Meeting of the College Woman's Club - subject "Our own [municipality?]" invited to speak at Mrs Eleanor L. Lattimore -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent time with Anna Shaw and attended a meeting of the College Woman's Club where they discussed a subject related to their own municipality and were invited to speak at Mrs. Eleanor L. Lattimore's place.

entries.fullText:
Anna Shaw spoke
at [?]
entries.summaryText: Anna Shaw spoke at an unknown location.

entries.fullText:
Anna Shaw
spoke at Syracuse
entries.summaryText: Anna Shaw spoke at Syracuse.

entries.fullText: David R. Anthony Jr called two hours in A.M. - and took dinner [Sarah ?] Mosher called and went to Depot with him at 5.30 - all well at home -
entries.summaryText: David R. Anthony Jr and Sarah Mosher visited and went to the Depot.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry for this date.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry for this date

entries.fullText:
Did not go to
Church -
entries.summaryText: Did not go to Church

entries.fullText:
Went to try on
black satin - enough
now to put in front
[breadths?] - & make waitst
& sleeves out of the their
[?] - came out -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony tried on black satin and made adjustments to the waist and sleeves.

entries.fullText:
writing letters & trying
to clean up take to
Anna -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote letters and cleaned up to take to Anna.

entries.fullText:
went to try on [?]
dress - it looks [nicely ?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony tried on a dress.

entries.fullText:
Ate Thanksgiving Turkey
at home with [?] Mrs
[Hair ?] with us -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had Thanksgiving dinner at home with Mrs [Hair ?].

entries.fullText:
] Hurly burly - Mrs.
Harper getting ready to
start at 7.45 for Washington
D.C. - she has been here 8 - wks
5 - of them at work on [letter crossed out] history
and I getting ready
for new job - Last [?]
came telegram from Mrs Cott
New York [will ?] not have a
booth - unless you give them
Rochester contribution - I answered
there can be no charge - [?]
then [?] went Wednesday directed
to Anthony Table -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper is leaving for Washington D.C. and Mrs. Cott is requesting a contribution from Rochester.

entries.fullText:
Took Train 9.05 -
for New York - Sister Mary
went to train with me -
rainy & drizzly day -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony takes a train to New York with Sister Mary on a rainy day.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]

entries.fullText:
New York - National
Woman Sufrage Bazaar Garden
Contest

This day finds
me ashamed that I
have done so little to
make poor people happy
- How can I begin
to bless people after the
fashion that other people
do - Dined out -
niece Anna O's - & Jean
Nash [Barons ?] -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony expresses shame for not doing enough to help poor people and dines out with her niece Anna O and Jean Nash [Barons ?].
